title: 109_s1888
content: The "Military Family Support Act of 2005" allows caregivers of individuals performing certain military service to use leave for family members. The "Federal Employees Program" defines a caregiver as an employee capable of caring for children or dependent family members of a qualified member of the Armed Forces during the covered period of service. An employee is defined as per section 6331 of title 5, United States Code. The term "family member" in the Federal Employees Program includes individuals who receive support from a qualified member of the Armed Forces and children, elderly adults, persons with disabilities, and others who cannot care for themselves in their absence. The term "qualified member of the Armed Forces" refers to a member of the Armed Forces. The Office of Personnel Management will establish a program to authorize a caregiver for a qualified member of the Armed Forces on active duty. Management shall establish a program to authorize a caregiver to use sick leave and other available leave during a covered period of service for a qualified member of the Armed Forces. The member must submit a written designation of the caregiver to the employing agency. The Office of Personnel Management will establish a program allowing a caregiver to use leave during a service period for a qualified member of the Armed Forces. A caregiver can be designated if they are the spouse of the member. Leave can only be used for caregiver-related purposes. Regulations must be prescribed within 120 days, and the program will end on December 31, 2007. The Voluntary Private Sector Leave Program allows caregivers to use leave during a service period for a qualified member of the Armed Forces. A caregiver is defined as an employee who is at least 21 years old and capable of self-care and caring for dependents. The program will end on December 31, 2007. The term "employee" in the program refers to an employee of a business entity participating in the program. The term "family member" includes individuals for whom the qualified member of the Armed Forces provides support and children under 19, elderly adults, persons with disabilities, and others unable to care for themselves. The term "qualified member of the armed forces" is also defined. The term "qualified member of the Armed Forces" refers to a member of a reserve component or active duty member eligible for special pay. The Secretary of Labor will establish a program for employees of certain business entities to use sick leave during a covered period, similar to annual leave. Business entities will be asked to voluntarily participate in the program. A qualified member of the Armed Forces can be designated as a caregiver. A qualified member of the Armed Forces can designate a caregiver for their family member during service. Leave can only be used for caregiver-related purposes. Regulations must be established within 120 days. The Secretary of Labor must establish regulations within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The program under this subsection will end on December 31, 2007. The Government Accountability Office will submit a report to Congress by June 30, 2007, evaluating the success of each program and providing recommendations for their continuance or termination.
